A recent ProPublica expos√© revealed how right-wing billionaire Harlan Crow has been showering Supreme Court justice Clarence Thomas with luxury gifts. In today‚Äôs featured story below, we reveal a new wrinkle to the scandal: Crow is directly tied to a disastrous new Supreme Court ruling that will strip environmental protections from millions of acres of precious wetlands.

Also:

  • On this week‚Äôs episode of The Audit, Dave and Josh discuss recent revelations about the TV series Lost having a ‚Äúpoisonous‚Äù working environment and author Naomi Klein helps pick apart climate change misinformation being presented in classrooms. Click here to hear the episode ‚Äî and be sure to subscribe!

Clarence Thomas‚Äô Billionaire Benefactor Tied To SCOTUS Bombshell

By Branko Marcetic

cards.calloutText: Follow us on Apple News and Google News to make sure you see our stories first, and to help make sure others see our breaking news as well.

cards.productDescription: Score a copy of our Citizens‚Äô Guide to Following the Money and Holding the Powerful Accountable, free with a paid subscription. The e-book gives you all the tools and tricks our reporting team uses to scrutinize power.

sections: Despite being caught in a swirling

, the Supreme Court continues to rule on cases and issue far-reaching decisions that shatter years of precedent to rewrite the country‚Äôs laws. For the moneyed interests who have spent big to financially influence the courts, this is very much according to plan. One of the court‚Äôs latest bombshell rulings shows just how handsomely the effort is paying off.

case, the Supreme Court dramatically narrowed the scope of the 1972 Clean Water Act in an act of judicial activism so brazen, even the Donald Trump-appointed Brett Kavanaugh accused the court of ‚Äúrewriting‚Äù the law and failing to ‚Äústick to the text.‚Äù
To do so, Justice Samuel Alito, writing for the majority, simply disposed of the statute‚Äôs

coverage of wetlands that are ‚Äúadjacent‚Äù to ‚Äúwaters of the United States,‚Äù redefining that word as meaning ‚Äúadjoining‚Äù ‚Äî a different word with a different meaning ‚Äî and claiming that only wetlands with a ‚Äúcontinuous surface connection‚Äù to protected waters were covered by the Clean Water Act. Environmental groups
protections for more than half of the country‚Äôs 118 million acres of wetlands.
for its linguistic games and overturning of long-standing precedent ‚Äî is directly tied up in the corruption scandal that has embroiled Supreme Court justice Clarence Thomas in particular.

in April, Thomas was revealed to have failed to disclose decades worth of generous gifts from right-wing billionaire Harlan Crow, the chairman and former CEO of Crow Holdings. The long-standing financial relationship between the two men ‚Äî which has included not just lavish holidays and
for the boy Thomas raised as his son, but even
in April, a trade group chaired by Ken Valach, currently the CEO of the development platform of Crow Holdings, was directly involved in the
case, pouring cold water over Thomas‚Äôs claim that Crow‚Äôs gifts weren‚Äôt a conflict of interest because the billionaire had no business before the court.

The National Multifamily Housing Council (NMHC), a trade group that counts three of Crow‚Äôs companies as dues-paying members, filed an amicus brief in the case, calling for the rollback of regulations they viewed as stifling housing construction. The NMHC has been a

of more expansive interpretations of the definition of ‚Äúwaters of the United States‚Äù (WOTUS) covered by the Clean Water Act, which among other things can hinder, delay, and or even outright block developers‚Äô plans if they might have an adverse impact on surrounding wetlands and other local water bodies.
But this already serious conflict of interest goes even deeper. The NHMC, whose board of directors Valach has served on since 2015, is a

of the Waters Advocacy Coalition (WAC), an alliance of various corporate trade groups dedicated to weakening the WOTUS definition, whose members span industries ranging from fossil fuels and mining to farming and real estate.

Since 2019 alone, the WAC has spent a total of $260,000 lobbying on one thing and one thing only: ‚Äúwaters of U.S. rulemaking,‚Äù or, as it put it in one filing, ‚Äúfederal legislative and administrative developments concerning the scope of federal regulatory authority over water bodies.‚Äù Not surprisingly, it wasted little time in, by
ruling the day it was announced for halting ‚Äúdecades of attempts to expand the federal government‚Äôs power over private land.‚Äù

in February 2022 about the Joe Biden administration‚Äôs planned expansion of the WOTUS rule, in which its objections to the administration‚Äôs proposed changes echoed the arguments Thomas and the rest of the court‚Äôs right-wing justices used in

. The new rule‚Äôs ‚Äúapproach to adjacency‚Äù ‚Äî where federal jurisdiction applied to wetlands ‚Äúwith only intermittent shallow subsurface connections,‚Äù or which were simply ‚Äúreasonably close‚Äù to waters already covered by the federal government ‚Äî raised ‚Äúimplementation concerns‚Äù via its ‚Äúvague terminology,‚Äù the comment stated.

The NHMC and WAC aren‚Äôt the only trade groups with links to Crow‚Äôs companies that have weighed in on the issue. Take the Real Estate Roundtable (RER), of which Crow Holdings CEO Michael Levy has been a member since 2017. The RER has likewise
amicus briefs to the Supreme Court on the
case in the past, albeit before Levy was a member, and it collaborates with the EPA via the agency‚Äôs

, through which, in the RER‚Äôs words, it ‚Äúadvocates for balanced environmental regulations‚Äù on issues that include wetlands programs under the Clean Water Act ‚Äúthat trigger land-use permitting requirements.‚Äù The WOTUS rule is among the suite of issues the RER has consistently lobbied on from 2014 to 2019, spending millions of dollars per quarter in the process.

There‚Äôs also NAIOP, the Commercial Real Estate Development Association, a developer trade group with whom Crow Holdings has numerous links. Clark Machemer, a senior managing director in the industrial group of Crow Holdings‚Äô development arm, sits on NAIOP‚Äôs executive committee and was a trustee of its political action committee in 2022, a position that, in the organization‚Äôs

, requires pledging a yearly donation of $5,000 and allows one to ‚Äúguide the agenda of the PAC and approve financial support allocated to elected officials and candidates.‚Äù Machemer has donated another $5,000 to NAIOP-PAC this year, according to an
, suggesting that he continues to serve as a trustee.

Besides this, Matt Kurucz, a managing director at the same development platform of Crow Holdings, is described as an ‚Äúactive member‚Äù of the NAIOP National Forums Groups ‚Äî a networking platform for commercial real estate professionals that convenes twice a year ‚Äî as well as a member of its Chicago chapter. Meanwhile, Crow Holdings has been one of the ‚Äúgrand sponsors‚Äù of its New Jersey chapter‚Äôs annual commercial real estate awards gala every year since 2019.
NAIOP similarly wasted no time in ‚Äú

, which it called a ‚Äúvictory for NAIOP‚Äù members, while noting it had been ‚Äúan issue on which NAIOP has been active on behalf of commercial real estate.‚Äù This was despite the fact that frequently changing the WOTUS definition was

NAIOP, too, has spent a cumulative total of millions lobbying on issues that include the WOTUS definition and federal jurisdiction over wetlands, from the first quarter of this year going all the way back to the first quarter of 2014, when it also lobbied for bills outright barring the EPA and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) from expanding the scope of protected waters without Congress‚Äô say-so.

Even besides this public paper trail, that Crow and his businesses will benefit from this ruling is hardly a secret. Crow Holdings‚Äô projects have often faced delays and regulatory obstacles due to their possible impact on local wetlands and other water bodies.
, last year the industrial branch of Crow Holdings

for authorization from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers under the Clean Water Act to build a one million-square-foot warehouse facility in Gordon County, Georgia, which was predicted to cause ‚Äúcumulative adverse impacts to 6.87 acres of wetland.‚Äù A search of the USACE permitting database shows that Crow Holdings Industrial has another permit pending, applied for in Chicago by NAIOP member Matt Kurucz, for water quality certification under
of the Clean Water Act, which determines whether or not a project that may cause discharge into waters of the United States can get a permit.

In 2020, Crow Holdings Industrial also requested an approved jurisdictional determination from the USACE on whether the water bodies on New Jersey‚Äôs Raccoon Island fall under the WOTUS definition. The

determined that 1111 wetlands making up nearly 136 acres that are adjacent to protected water bodies fall under federal regulation, with eight of them directly abutting those water bodies or artificially separated from them by roads ‚Äî something that may have disqualified them from federal protection under the court‚Äôs rewriting of the Clean Water Act last week. Since then, development of the site appears to have been
to another company, Floodgate Road LLC, which is planning a series of warehouses on the land.

This is far from the first time Crow Holdings has had to navigate regulatory hurdles surrounding wetlands to get its projects off the ground. A proposal by the firm to create speculative warehouse space in Oak Creek, Wisconsin, last year faced
in part due to the numerous wetlands on the proposed space, with the local planning department
to this when recommending against the project‚Äôs approval. An ultimately successful apartment complex project in 2008 that involved filling 4,800 square feet of wetlands was
by a legal challenge from locals over its environmental impact.

proposed by Trammell Crow Residential was voted down unanimously in 2006 by a local planning board, which pointed out that the company‚Äôs site plan sat on a wetland buffer zone and was likely to drain water from the wetlands. Little wonder, then, that both Trammell Crow Residential and Trammell Crow  and Trammell Crow Commercial have been
of Wetland Studies and Solutions, Inc., a consulting firm that helps companies with Clean Water Act permits ‚Äî and which is
as a ‚Äúbenefactor‚Äù of NAIOP‚Äôs Northern Virginia chapter. (Firms that

Whether through quicker approval of projects, fewer regulatory restrictions to wade through, or by neutering the ability of local residents to oppose controversial projects, it‚Äôs not difficult to see how the Supreme Court decision that Clarence Thomas just provided a pivotal vote for will end up serving his benefactor‚Äôs business interests.
As former conservative activist Rob Schneck

, the purpose of lavishing Supreme Court justices with expensive gifts and opulent dinners isn‚Äôt to sway them toward a particular political philosophy. Clarence Thomas was a conservative long before he met Harlan Crow for
entirely unrelated to the billionaire‚Äôs personal generosity.
The point, Schneck explained, was to create what

termed an ‚Äúecosystem of support‚Äù that would encourage them to be bolder in their judicial activism. Sometimes that would benefit the benefactors by opening the door to imposing their personal, regressive social vision on others. Sometimes it would benefit them by directly assisting their personal business interests, as it has in the
case, which will make it easier for Crow‚Äôs companies and other real estate developers to disrupt and damage wetlands without legal or regulatory challenge.
Yet the clear, monumental conflict of interest involved in
and the obvious unseemliness of ultrarich donors plying justices with luxurious gifts should not just raise questions about the legitimacy of this ruling. It should also feed further
about the legitimacy of an entire Supreme Court
This article was first published in
, offering socialist perspectives on politics, economics, and culture.
